HQSKpLYfRqBWMCJDe398aw.text: Unassuming on the outside, but this small place has great and fast food at very reasonable prices.   Don't go to Bluerapa thai food. Come here instead.

IdxTsowPefV_2GGAOeFBrA.text: Very good gyros and cheap too. The baklava was not as good we expected so giving one less star. Still musy try anyone looking for good gyros in town.

pRtUM1Gm5xtItkku5Ha4AQ.text: Chicken Souvlaki tasted mediocre with barely any seasoning. Chicken Gyros were just OK. Service and prices were all OK as well.

XE3cWXSQ94Q0nUNpikNiOQ.text: If you are in the area, and need a quick alternative to a chippy, ignore the exterior and try the food out here. It tasted great :)

hUKmKlPl-s_QFKnaLXVKXQ.text: Traveling from Los Angeles. We found this most amazing Greek restaurant. The service was superb. But, the food was even better than that. The Chicken greek salad, the Chicken gyros and the wine were so amazing that we ate there multiple times during our 2 night stay.  The owner and his family were so friendly and efficient. Probably one of the BEST meals we had on our 17 day U.K. trip.

XmWlIP56NP2oEffEs0259g.text: One of my most favourite fast food restaurants in Edinburgh. Chicken gyros is amazing. The chicken is very well prepared. Pita is nice. Dessert, baklava, is lovely!

photos.caption: Photo of Ola Kala - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Gyros
Photo of Ola Kala - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Bourgiordi
Photo of Ola Kala - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Amazing pitta

E2lh4F64sfUcDzr8jn6WkQ.text: An original Greek souvlaki (pork skewer) and mpifteki (beef mince meat with herbs)?  With home-made fries? Tzatziki (garlic yoghurt salad) and other Greek dishes?   And some original Greek soft drinks and the famous Greek pitta bread?   Oh yes!!! I was looking forward to trying out this place!   Things I wasn't impressed with: on the souvlaki portion (three pork skeweres, pitta bread, some chopped tomatoes and onions along with chips) there was no tzatziki! Come on, you guys are all Greek in there and you should now that these things go together.   No alcohol served, at least for now.   On my 2nd visit the service was good and punctual, around 6-7 people working in it. It's not an actual restaurant, it's closer to a kebab place I would say, but believe me, you need to try it (at least once!).   Now about my first visit... Well, it was on the 2nd day they opened, three people only working there, people standing in the queue waiting to order, and giving up after 15 minutes or so. I was lucky enough to find a sit, while my persistent friend was standing right on the cashier to give an order: it took 35 mins to just give the order and another 15 mins to be served!!! We were not happy at all, but we were hungry and wanted badly to try their food.   Will I go back? Yes, assuming there's no big queue!!

photos.caption: Photo of Ola Kala - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Bifteki (beef mince meat with herbs) with house-chips and Greek pita bread
Photo of Ola Kala - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Souvlaki dish - three pork skewers with house chips

IxXAlkG6I-J5dpWFt3Vx9A.text: Their food is still good and authentic, but I have to pay extra for tzatziki (yougurt sauce) in my gyros. Given the prices of the place they should include it like every greek place does or even raise the price of it but not charge us an extra for it, that's a joke (and a bad one). At least they fixed the option to add tzatziki sauce in the gyros ithrough online delivery (via deliveroo), because initially we had to call them each time to add it at the order and the staff was giving us attitude because the charge had already been made online (not our fault though.)

fg3HhcdCd8Eup4U3WxBsaw.text: I've been back maybe 30 times (yes that is not an exaggeration) since the first review and the service, food and overall experience has never been less than 5 stars. There are about only 3 places I eat in Edinburgh. Scran and Scallie (they allow dogs), Imperial Palace (dim sum cravings) and here at Ola Kala.   My standard order now is maybe the feta cheese dip, a pita, the potatoes with kefalortiri, main course of gyros and a green greek coke. Oh also you have to try the square baklava. Is made with walnuts and cinnamon. Some of the best I have ever tried.   Also they have tables outside for summer.   TLDR - Still the best kebab (gyros) in Edinburgh if not Scotland.

qAuSwKsRMWSGdrcXV-IShw.text: Really like this place; i usually go for the chicken gyro and the soutzoukaki gyro (meat with melted cheese in the middle) and both are simply delicious; yhe people working there are really nice and the price is quite cheap. I highly recommend this place

dVSHEugzwa4N7QWAUsn-mg.text: Good place to grab a quick bite, I ordered a gyro pita and received it in a couple minutes. Good quality ingredients, and reasonably priced. Didn't try the baklava, but it looked very fresh

lAbZjYZ1LLPfWotKsVfJ3Q.text: Great souvlaki and a nice environment! Recent change in management helped the place. Prices could be a bit better though.

2zYF7KoBi71_MRQsmil6Kw.text: Oh so yummy!!! I had the pork gyro for 4 pounds and my boyfriend has the pork gyro plate for 7 pounds. Definitely will be coming back. The price and the food was exactly what I've been looking for in Edinburgh!! Nice staff and clean, even have a carafe of Tap water! Thank you for a yummy lunch!!!
